awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Intelligent Representations: How to Blend Physical and Virtual Representations by Adapting to the Individual Student's Needs in Real Time
awd_abstract_narration:
Adaptive educational technologies can much improve students' learning in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) domains. A particular strength of these technologies is that they can provide interactive models that visualize complex concepts. Educational technologies typically use virtual models that students manipulate via mouse or keyboard. Yet, physical models that students manipulate with their hands can be more intuitive because they relate abstract concepts to students? bodily experiences in the real world. This CAREER project examines how best to integrate physical models into adaptive educational technologies. The project will focus on a domain where models play a crucial role in instruction: undergraduate chemistry. A series of experiments at 2-year and 4-year colleges will test whether physical or virtual models are most effective for particular concepts, in which order to present them, and how to help students make connections among them. Further, the team will develop a technology that can assess how students manipulate physical models. Results will be consolidated in a comprehensive theory of how physical and virtual models affect student learning. The results will help instructors select the best model for their students. The team will build on the results to develop an educational technology that adaptively selects physical and virtual models that is most helpful to the individual student given his/her learning progress. This research will yield a new type of educational technologies that blend physical and virtual models and that can adapt to individual students' bodily interactions. Such technologies can make STEM concepts more accessible to students with diverse backgrounds. Further, by involving students and instructors from 2-year colleges who often lack access to technology innovations, the project will broaden participation and enhance socioeconomic equality in STEM.

Students' difficulties in thinking in terms of visual representations jeopardize their learning in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) domains such as chemistry. Physical (tangible) and virtual representation modes have complementary benefits for students' learning. Yet, there is no comprehensive theory of how representation modes complement one another when students learn abstract content. The goal of this CAREER project is to develop such theory. Because effective combinations of physical and virtual representations are concept-, action-, and student-specific, they are likely too complex for instructors to achieve without support. Educational technologies can offer such support, but they cannot interface with physical representations. Hence, another goal of this CAREER project is to translate theory about representation modes into adaptive educational technologies that intelligently blend physical and virtual representations. A series of experiments in 2- and 4-year college chemistry will investigate how physical and virtual representations complement one another, how best to sequence them, and how best to help students make connections among them. User studies with instructors and students will investigate how educational technology design can address educational needs and systemic constraints in real learning contexts and how to support instructors in combining representation modes effectively. Further project activities will expand the intelligent blending framework to STEM domains in K-12 contexts. The project will contribute new theory about how physical and virtual representations complement one another. It will yield practical recommendations for the design of educational technologies that adapt to individual students' body-based interactions. A concrete deliverable will be an adaptive educational technology for 2- and 4-year college chemistry, available for free and disseminated to diverse populations. By including 2-year-colleges and by making this research applicable to STEM education in K-16 contexts, this project may broaden participation and enhance socioeconomic equality in many STEM domains.

por.por_cntn:
Physical interactions play a role in students’ learning. Instructors have to make important decisions between physical and virtual interactions, for example when students interact with representations that can be presented in a physical format (e.g., hands-on models) or a virtual format (e.g., simulations on a computer).

This project aimed to enhance chemistry education by integrating physical and virtual representations of atoms and molecules. The project developed and evaluated technology-supported instructional activities and cognitive models that used physical and virtual representations. The activities were designed to help students understand over 50 chemistry concepts.

The first step in the project was to conduct a theoretical cognitive task analysis to understand how physical and virtual representations can help or hinder students’ understanding of the chemistry concepts. The analysis uncovered embodied affordances (e.g., haptic and tactile experiences) offered by these representations as well as conceptual affordances (e.g., their ability to highlight conceptually relevant aspects). However, the analysis revealed that embodied affordances often conflict with conceptual affordances, so that instructors may have to decide between representations that have a beneficial embodied affordance but a suboptimal conceptual affordance for a given concept.

The second step was to conduct an empirical cognitive task analysis with students from the target population. This analysis supported findings from the theoretical cognitive task analysis, using think-aloud protocols, body movement data, and gesture data.

The third step was to develop instructional materials for the following experiments. Experiment 1 compared physical and virtual representations that emphasized different affordances. Results showed that representations that prioritized embodied affordances enhanced students’ learning of simple content knowledge, whereas conceptual affordances enhanced complex learning outcomes. These findings yielded insights into how instructional materials can resolve the conflicts identified in the cognitive task analyses, by prioritizing different types of affordances depending on the learning goal.

The fourth step was to compare different ways of sequencing physical and virtual representations that offer different affordances. Experiment 2 addressed this goal and suggests that early instruction should prioritize embodied affordances to enhance later learning with representations that prioritize conceptual affordances.

The fifth step was to develop a cognitive model that can infer students’ knowledge based on their interactions with representations. For physical representations, this means that the model has to capture students’ interactions with non-computerized representations. The team created an app that allows students to photograph their physical representations for assessment, achieving 98% accuracy in object detection. The resulting cognitive model was integrated into Chem Tutor, a technology-based learning software, that gives students feedback on their interactions with physical and virtual representations.

The sixth step was to examine how to help students connect physical and virtual experiences with representations, using the Chem Tutor system. A series of studies examined this question, with the final study still ongoing. Results thus far suggest that early embodied experiences with physical representations help students make sense of virtual representations, thereby enhancing their learning with virtual representations.

Several project activities served to disseminate project outcomes. Interactions with instructors at 2-year and 4-year colleges informed the development and iterative improvement of Chem Tutor activities, effectively addressing student misconceptions. Chem Tutor was disseminated to high schools and colleges, receiving positive feedback. A teacher workshop in fostered connections with math teachers, leading to additional studies in math education to further broaden the research findings. The study revealed patterns in students' use of physical manipulatives, providing insights into when these tools are most effective. Collaboration with a UW-Madison chemistry instructor led to the adaptation of Chem Tutor activities for use in a chemistry course, with plans for continued use and improvement. Courses on interactive visual representations in educational technologies received positive evaluations, with students noting the value of learning to use and analyze visual tools effectively. Similar courses at another institution were also well-received. Mentoring undergraduate and graduate students from various disciplines enriched the research process. The project has yielded 18 publications. Project outcomes were presented at numerous conferences, invited external talks, and internal talks.

Altogether, this project has significantly advanced the understanding and use of physical and virtual representations in chemistry education and beyond, improving instructional activities and tools, and contributing to better learning outcomes.
